newsitem.title: USA: CheckFree acquires Intuit's bill, bank services.
newsitem.headline: CheckFree acquires Intuit's bill, bank services.

text.p: CheckFree Corp. will acquire Intuit Services Corp., the electronic bill payment and bank services unit of Intuit Corp., in a stock deal worth about $258.3 million, the companies said Monday.
At the same time, Intuit will buy a stake of about 23 percent in CheckFree, a leading provider of check processing services.
The acquisition will expand CheckFree's customers for home banking and bill payment services to over 180 financial institutions and more than one million consumers.
Intuit said the sale allows it to reallocate management and focus on its core software and growing Internet businesses.

Columbus, Ohio-based CheckFree said it will offer 12.6 million shares of its common stock for Intuit Services. CheckFree's stock rose $2.5625, while Intuit climbed $2.125 to $32.25 on Nasdaq in late morning trading. Intuit said it plans to sell about 2 million CheckFree shares acquired in the transaction.

Intuit has agreed to pay CheckFree any shortfall if its unit's revenues for the year ending July 31, 1997 fall below $46 million. Intuit Service accounted for less than 3 percent of Intuit's revenues in fiscal 1996.
CheckFree said it will merge the unit's operations into its existing processing systems.
The deal is expected to close before Dec. 31, subject to regulatory and stockholder approval.

"This acquisition makes us the go-to service company for electronic commerce, and with the shift from paper to electronic commerce clearly underway, that's a good position to be in," said Peter Kight, chairman and CEO of CheckFree.

"This combination does what the financial institutions have asked for -- it creates an open, completely invisible transaction processing architecture for them to use that supports all leading interfaces."

CheckFree said its open processing architecture allows financial institutions to deliver home banking and bill payment through personal computers, touch-tone phones and the Internet. Additionally, CheckFree's processing architecture allows financial institutions to offer multiple software interfaces for PC-based home banking and bill payment, including Intuit's Quicken and BankNOW, Microsoft Money, Managing Your Money, HomeATM and other bank-branded software.
Knight said the overall acceleration of growth at CheckFree resulting from the acquisition of Intuit Service would result in more jobs at the company.

Separately, Intuit said its losses widened to $22.0 million, or 48 cents a share, in the quarter ended July 31 from $1.4 million, or 3 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenues rose 26 percent to $91.1 million from $72.4 million.
The latest results include an $8 million acquisition charge, increased spending in customer service and technical support, and start-up expenses in bill payment processing at Intuit Services.
Intuit said it typically expects to report operating losses for the July and October quarters because of operating expenses to develop the updated versions of tax and other products.

Mountain View, Calif.-based Intuit produces TurboTax, the best-selling tax preparation software; and QuickBooks, the most popular small business accounting software. Its Quicken programme is the leading personal finance software.
